properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First accumulating snowfall of the season expected for many areas. Total snowfall: near 5 cm, with higher amounts over elevated terrain. Locations: central, western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: mainly late Monday night through Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin over western Newfoundland near midnight Monday night, and will spread into central and northern parts of the island by early Tuesday morning. The snow will change to rain over most areas by midday on Tuesday, but may persist through Tuesday afternoon and evening over parts of the Northern and Baie Verte Peninsulas, especially over higher terrain. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-10-26T09:46:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T17:47:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4103368092.2020
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls continue in the lee of Lake Winnipeg as cold west winds blow across the lake, with Berens River reporting close to 10 cm of snow by mid-afternoon. Further localized accumulations of up to 15 cm are possible by the time the snow tapers off overnight. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T12:25:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T20:26:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1844885814.2020
Area: Poplar River, Berens River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A frontal system will move across central and northern parts of the interior today through Monday morning. Snow associated with this system is expected to start late today. The snow will change to ice pellets mixed with freezing rain overnight. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected by Monday morning. As the front moves eastwards, the freezing rain or ice pellets are expected to ease on Monday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T03:15:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T11:16:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2570696423.2020
Area: Chilcotin, Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Bulkley Valley, Lakes District, Stuart - Nechako
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A frontal system moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska will cross the Yukon on Monday. As it approaches, strong easterly winds of 70 to 100 km/h near the Richardson Mountains are forecast to develop. These winds combined with falling snow will give blizzard conditions to the area beginning Monday morning. Conditions will improve Monday evening as the system exits the territory. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T04:41:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T12:42:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3135846370.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A frontal system moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska will bring snow to much of the Yukon beginning later today in the southwest and spreading to the central Yukon tonight. Snow will ease Monday morning in the southwest as the system crosses the area but persist until Monday evening elsewhere. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T04:39:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T12:40:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1518847878.2020
Area: Dawson, Mayo, Beaver Creek, Pelly - Carmacks, Whitehorse, Faro - Ross River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts from 15 to 25 cm are expected today through Monday. A frontal system, moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska will spread significant snowfall amounts from central BC to the southern Yukon. Snow will begin this morning from Teslin to Dease Lake and reach Watson Lake to Prince George by early this evening. Snow will ease for most areas on Monday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T03:02:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T11:03:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2980450275.2020
Area: Yellowhead, Williston, Prince George, McGregor, Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park, Watson Lake, Dease Lake, Cassiar Mountains, Teslin, Atlin

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts from 15 to 25 cm are expected today through Monday. A frontal system, moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska will spread significant snowfall amounts from central BC to the southern Yukon. Snow will begin this morning from Teslin to Dease Lake and reach Watson Lake to Prince George by early this evening. Snow will ease for most areas on Monday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First significant early season snowfall likely on Monday. Locations: northern New Brunswick. Time span: Monday afternoon and Monday night. Remarks: Indications are that snow will begin over northern New Brunswick Monday afternoon and continue Monday night, though a changeover to rain is possible Monday night over some regions. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible; however, more accumulation is likely over higher terrain where temperatures will be colder. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T06:04:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T14:05:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0567832283.2020

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Hurricane Epsilon. Summary of basic information at 9:30 p.m. NDT. Location: Near 40.1 North 57.6 West. About 815 kilometres south-southwest of Cape Race. Maximum sustained winds: 130 kilometres per hour. Present movement: Northeast at 35 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 958 millibars. Hurricane Epsilon will skirt the southern extremes of the southern Grand banks on Sunday and then move rapidly away from Atlantic Canadian waters Sunday night. Epsilon will not have any direct impacts on Canadian land areas. However, swell waves are expected to build along the southern coastlines of Nova Scotia and Newfoundland tonight and Sunday. The largest waves reaching the coast are expected over the southern Avalon Peninsula where waves of 4 to 6 metres are expected. Over the south coast of Newfoundland from the Burin Peninsula and west to Port aux Basques, waves of 3 to 5 metres are expected. Along the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia, waves of 3 to 4 metres are likely. Rain from a developing trough of low pressure well ahead of Epsilon is spreading over southeastern Newfoundland this evening, but the center of Epsilon will track well offshore near the southeastern corner of the Grand Banks early on Sunday. Gale to storm force winds are expected over southeastern offshore waters. Over the southern edge of the Southeastern Grand Banks, hurricane force winds will likely occur. Waves over the southeastern offshore waters are expected to be generally 6 to 9 metres except over the southern edges of the southern Grand Banks where waves of 10 to 13 metres are expected. This is the last scheduled bulletin from the CHC on Hurricane Epsilon. Forecaster(s): Hatt ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-10-26T02:35:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-24T23:26:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3960530919.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast
properties.Author: Environment Canada
